awd_titl_txt: Problems in Extremal and Probabilistic Combinatorics
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal concentrates on two areas of research: the extremal theory of graphs and hypergraphs, and the theory of discrete random structures. Both belong to the main stream of contemporary discrete mathematics and enjoy a broad range of applications in mathematics and computer science.  Extremal theory of graphs and hypergraphs is at the frontier of combinatorics, demanding more and more sophisticated proof techniques. Some of the notoriously difficult problems have remained open for more than 50 years, stimulating steady progress of research. Randomness continues to play a fundamental role in demonstrating the existence of combinatorial structures with desired properties, in modeling real life large networks, as well as in the design of efficient algorithms.  The aim of the proposed research is to get a better understanding of some phenomena occurring in both these areas, and how they interact. Our specific goals are to study to what extent the minimum degree in graphs and hypergraphs determines their structure and to transfer classical results, of extremal and Ramsey type, to sparse random environments.

The project, owing to its international character, will serve as a means of further development of collaboration between the best researchers from various parts of the world. The investigators will work towards popularizing the results of their research by publishing in high-quality journals and presenting addresses at prestigious international conferences. Having access to students, both graduate and undergraduate, they will be in a position to disseminate their achievements also at these levels of academic education. In particular, the problems described in this proposal will be a good source of doctoral research topics for current and future students.

por.por_cntn:
The research carried out with the support of this grant focused on the extremal 
theory of graphs and hypergraphs.  As expected, randomness and 
quasi-randomness played a fundamental role, as did sophisticated, purely 
combinatorial arguments, some of them very recent, such as the absorbing method.  
Several papers that were written with this support addressed extremal problems either by 
resorting to probabilistic arguments, or by regularity type methods, making use
 of quasi-randomness in a strong way.  Some other papers approached
combinatorial problems of a purely probabilistic nature, and the
understanding of randomness has been refined. Most of the results obtained in this 
research have already been published or have been accepted for publication in 
international refereed journals, and there are still a number of papers submitted for 
publication.  Over 30 publications will acknowledge the support of this grant.

As illustrations, we mention that some long-standing problems in the area of
 quasirandom hypergraphs were addressed and solved in [Reiher, Rödl, and 
Schacht, Embedding tetrahedra into quasirandom hypergraphs; On a Turán problem 
in weakly quasirandom 3-uniform hypergraphs].  The problem of how sparse universal 
random graphs can be with respect to bounded degree spanning subgraphs was
 investigated in [Delamonica, Kohayakawa, Rödl, Rucinski, An improved upper bound
 in the density of universal random graphs.  Random Struct. Algorithms. 46 (2)].  
Graph theoretic methods were applied to investigate a circle of problems in additive
 combinatorics and probabilistic additive combinatorics.  For instance, in [Dellamonica, 
Kohayakawa, Lee, Rödl, and Samotij, The number of B_h-sets of a given cardinality] 
we investigated a natural enumeration problem in the area and we determined 
asymptotically the maximum size of a B_h-set that appears in a randomly set of 
integers.

The supported research involved the collaboration of senior experts from Brazil, 
Germany and Poland and young researchers and graduate students from
 several countries.  The PI and his collaborators were active in presenting their
 results in conferences, workshops and seminars taking place in the Americas, 
Europe and Asia.  The training of  graduated students involved the research
 undertaken under this grant.
